data.title: Everything needs to be PERFECT!
data.statement:
In number theory, a perfect number is a positive integer that is equal to the sum of its positive divisors, excluding the number itself.
For instance, 6 has divisors 1, 2 and 3 (excluding itself), and 1 + 2 + 3 = 6, so 6 is a perfect number.

In a given list [[l]] of length [[n]], filter out the non-perfect numbers and print either the resulted list in the same format <<in ascending order>> or the string {{NONE}} if [[l]] includes no perfect number.

<<Note:>> You might probably need to optimize the loops there...
data.stubGenerator:
read n:int
loopline n l:long
write perfect numbers
data.inputDescription:
<<First line:>> [[n]] a positive number representing the length of the input list.
<<Second line:>> [[l]] a space-delimited list of [[n]] positive numbers [ [[l_1]], [[l_2]], ..., [[l_n]] ].
data.outputDescription: [[p]] a space-delimited list of perfect numbers <<in ascending order>> or the string {{NONE}} if none was found.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

In number theory, a perfect number is a positive integer that is equal to the sum of its positive divisors, excluding the number itself.
For instance, 6 has divisors 1, 2 and 3 (excluding itself), and 1 + 2 + 3 = 6, so 6 is a perfect number.

In a given list l of length n, filter out the non-perfect numbers and print either the resulted list in the same format in ascending order or the string NONE if l includes no perfect number.

Note: You might probably need to optimize the loops there...
Input
First line: n a positive number representing the length of the input list.
Second line: l a space-delimited list of n positive numbers [ l_1, l_2, ..., l_n ].
Output
p a space-delimited list of perfect numbers in ascending order or the string NONE if none was found.
Constraints
0 < l_k < 100 000 000 (max. 8 digits)
Example
Input
9
1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9
Output
6
